summary.p: 2 fol. on parchment; Shelfmark: E 16264 D; Qurʾānic Text: Q 16:2-16:14, Q 39:47-39:68; Script style: Fragment 1: kūfī C.Ia, Fragment 2: close to kūfī B.I; Estimated date of production: Fragment 1 700-800 CE; Fragment 2 bevor 750 CE.

This shelfmark entails two fragments from different manuscripts. Fragment 1 (21 lines, 324 x 208mm) shows a passage from sura 39. Fragment 2 (5 lines, 82 x 155mm) shows a passage from sura 16. Fragment 1 probably belongs to the same codex as Vat. ar. 1784 and other two sister fragments Arabe 332 from BnF in Paris and KFQ 49 from the Khalili Collection in London.
The catalogue of Arabic manuscripts kept by the University Museums in Philaldelphia, written by Giorgio Levi Della Vida gives the following information (Levi Della Vida 1981, p. 155f.):

"122. Inv. E. 16264 D. 2nd-3rd century A.H./8th-9th century A.D. ? White, thin parchment. Two fragments belonging to two different copies have been put together under a single glass. Dimensions of a: 32.4 x 20.8 cm.; of b: 8.2 x 15.5 cm. The full length of the sheet, except for the loss of a line at the bottom and of both margins, and about two thirds of the original width are preserved in a, on which both faces are inscribed with twenty broken lines in brownish ink. b is a fragment of the inner half of a sheet, and bears on both faces the former, and respectively the latter, halves of four lines, with traces of a previous fifth line. The original size of the sheet must have been ca. 27 x 31 cm. From the Ellen W. Harrison Collection. a. Recto: Kor. 39,47 (48) [الار]ض – 56 (57) ا[لسٰخرين]. Verso: 39,58 (59) [او] تقول – 69 [وو]ضـ[ـع].The script presents a close similarity to Geschichte des Qorāns III Plate III (Istanbul Saray, from Medina) and no. 38 in the Vatican Library (see G. Levi Della Vida, Frammenti coranici, p. 29). The characteristic letters (isolated and final qāf, lām, mīm, and yāʾ; medial ḥāʾ and ʿayn) have the same archaic aspect. Here as there diacritical signs and vowel marks, expressed by slanting strokes and red dots, occur but rarely. Three slanting parallel strokes are used as verse dividers. Two five-verse dividers, in the shape of a red disk, appear on recto line 15 and verso line 10 at the end of verses 53 and 68, which are 50 and 65 according to Baṣran and Medinese traditions (see A. Spitaler, Die Verszählung des Koran nach islamischer Ueberlieferung [in Sitzungsberichte der philos.-hist. Abtl. der Bayerischen Akademie der Wissenschaften, 1935, Heft 11], p.55). b. Recto: Kor. 16,1 سحٰنه – 4 نطفة. Verso: 16,11 [يتفكرو]ن – 14 لـ[ـتـ]ـا[كلوا]. In verse 13 instead of لاية the reading is الاية, which probably is nothing more than a scribal error. The script is thinner and more elongated than in a. The lower end of alif is bent towards the right. Isolated and medial ḥāʾs have archaic forms. The top of isolated and final nūn is only slightly rounded. Final yāʾ is reversed. Diacritical signs are expressed by short and heavy strokes, approaching the shape of dots. Vowels are marked by red dots. There are no dividers."

support.p: Text division of the fragment 1: The group of three oblique dashes mark the end of a verse. Every tenth verse is marked by a circle filled with red ink with a dot in the center. The three sister fragments Vat. ar. 1784, Arabe 332 and KFQ 49 show the same verse separators.

summary.p: Fragment 1 (fol. 1) is written in a style close to kūfī C.Ia influenced by the early kūfī script style B.I and ḥiǧāzī IV. The letter ʾalif resembles the C.Ia group. Within a word, the letters ǧīm/ḥāʾ/ḫāʾ cross the base line diagonally (not after a denticle) as those of B.I group, unlike those of C.Ia, where the letter rests on the base line. The letter ʿayn in the initial position is close to C.Ia but shows an interesting form of the upper hook: the hook has a rounded shape that looks like a dot, that cannot be seen in any other script groups. Within a word the letter resembles the B.Ib group, the right hand antenna being vertical. The letter qāf isolated or in the final position is similar to those of C.Ia group. The initial and medial forms of the letter hāʾ, alongside with the letter nūn in the final or isolated position and the letter mīm at the end of a word show a similar form seen in the ḥiǧāzī IV manuscript Saray 50385 from Istanbul, the script of which also shows similarities to the C.Ia group. As for the ligature lām-ʾalif, the form is similar to the C.Ia group.

F. Déroche relates the script of the sister fragment BnF Arabe 332 to the C.Ia group (See Déroche 1983: p. 77). The script of the second sister fragment, KFQ 49 from the Khalili Collections in London is labelled by Déroche as 'unclassified', although he links the manuscript with BnF Arabe 332 (See Déroche 1992: p. 129).
The manuscript shows occasional diacritical marking, but no signs of vocalisation.

Fragment 2 (fol. 2): Due to the heavily damaged condition of fol. 2, limited amount of characters are available for the analysis of the script. The script of the second fragment is close to the early kūfī script style B.I. ʾAlif has a short lower return in the independent form, the shaft shows a slight inclination to the right. The form is close to B.Ib group. The letter ḥāʾ in the middle of a word on fol. 2v is written like a bar across the base line and is similar to the B.Ib group. In the independent position on fol. 2r the letter has a round generous hook which is different from the form attested in B.I. A similar form of the letters ǧīm/ḥāʾ/ḫāʾ in the indemendent position is seen in the ḥiǧāzī III manuscript Arabe 330 (a). Mīm at the end of a word is similar to the B.Ia group with a tail that curves upwords. Nūn in the final or isolated position has a long vertical body with a short return at the bottom, which is similar to B.II. The ligature lām-ʾalif shows an interesting variant: In the independent porition it has a rounder base than in B.I forms. The two shafts of the letters curve towards each other as in B.Ia. In general, some of the features of the script such as ʾalif, mīm at the end of a word, nūn and the ligature lām-ʾalif are similar to the kūfī B fragments from Qatar National Library.
Diacritics are indicated by short strokes. Vocalisation is made by red dots.
